Jeff, one thing I don't completely understand about your graphs (e.g. gra=
ph 1) is that the number of nodes in the champion goes up even when fitness=
 is not going up.  If you have elitism, wouldn't the same champion stick ar=
ound unchanged?  Perhaps you are seeing that new individuals occasionally c=
ome in with the same fitness as the champion, but it would be very surprisi=
ng if that is happening on every single generation.  Yet that would seem to=
 be the only possibility with the number of champion nodes going up so rapi=
dly even while fitness is flatlined.  So what is going on during the fitnes=
s plateau?  Which genomes exactly are being measured to get the node counts=
?

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Jeff Clune <jclune@...> wrote:
>
> Hel=
lo all-
> 
> I have been noticing in many of my HyperNEAT runs recently tha=
t the number
> of CPPN nodes is shooting up as a steep linear function of t=
ime
> (generations), and is relatively unaffected by the fitness trajectory=
 of the
> run. 
> 
> See here, for example
> 
> https://www.msu.edu/~jclune=
/delme/CPPN-Node-Bloat-1.png
> 
> Sometimes it gets really pathological, wi=
th almost 25 CPPN nodes being added
> every 100 generations, such as here:
=
> 
> https://www.msu.edu/~jclune/delme/CPPN-Node-Bloat-2.png
> 
> Oddly, an=
d interestingly, the runs in this second figure where the CPPN node
> count=
 linearly increases are in a changing environment and those runs where
> th=
e CPPN node count flatlines (at a healthy level) are in a constant
> enviro=
nment.
> 
> Are any of you seeing such bloat?
> 
> One problem is that it m=
akes the runs slow to a crawl, because running
> populations with 200-node =
genomes is really slow. Moreover, I doubt
> evolution can make too much pro=
gress with that many nodes (although I have
> seen fitness continue to incr=
ease even with such large genomes).
> 
> I have tried dropping the MutateAd=
dNodeProbability from 0.03 to 0.003 and
> that definitely changes the slope=
 of the line, but it still linearly
> increases. The good news is that it d=
oes not affect fitness to much.
> 
> Any thoughts? 
> 
> 
> Kind regards,
>=
 Jeff Clune
> 
> Digital Evolution Lab, Michigan State University
> jclune@=
...
> www.msu.edu/~jclune
>
